newsitem.title: USA: Copper prices jump to highest level in a year.
newsitem.headline: Copper prices jump to highest level in a year.

text.p: Copper prices steamed to the highest level in a year Tuesday on the threat of labour problems in key producer Chile.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, May copper closed up 1.60 cents at $1.181 a pound.
Copper inventories have eroded steadily over the past several months due to the buoyant global economy, and consumption has gone up at a time of labour troubles in Chile.
A brief strike Tuesday at the Chilean state smelting company Enami's Ventanas plant reminded the market of supply disruptions that could hit copper.
The strike was called to protest against the Chilean government's reported plans to privatise Enami and state oil firm Enap, said a union leader.
Analysts said the market also may have been expecting that the Federal Reserve was going to leave interest rates unchanged at Tuesday's policy-setting meeting.
"This was a fairly explosive rally ... if there is no interest rate rise that would be very good for the metals," said Robin Bahr, an analyst for the brokerage house Brandeis.
After the close, the Fed said that it was holding short-term interest rates unchanged.
